Listening to R. Sargent Shriver, Jr. is
just like listening to Hubert Humphrey.
Norman Mailer used to enjoy confusing
people by introducing himself as Lyndon
Johnson's dwarf alter ego. Shriver could
pull a similar act, only billed as the rich
man's Humphrey. Aside from the
shrillness, what did Sarge have to say?
Well, he started by pointing out the
long and distinguished history of his
family in Maryland: his ancestor, David
Shriver, served in the Stamp Act Congress
and was a friend of Charles Carroll of
Carrollton, signer of the Declaration of
Independence and a fellow wealthy
Catholic enlightened landlord; another
relative, Andrew Shriver, President of the
Maryland Bar Association, donated Shriver
Hall to the University—and don't you
forget it. His relative recital probably
turned a lot of people off, but Shriver is
irrepressible. Nothing gets the man down.
Who else would once again foist himself
on the American electorate after the
trouncing he received with St. George in
1972. Shriver has never been elected to
any office; he overcompensates for this
fact by boasting that he is a manger, an
executive. He told his audience that he
would make a lousy Senator or

Congressman, but that the Presidency was
the right job for him. He stressed his
diplomatic career as Ambassador to
France and his administrative experience
as Director of the Peace Corps and head of
O.E.O. as suitable qualifications for the

APL conversion committee
asks weapons moratorium
By RICHARD FREEMAN
and
STAN BECKE R
Twenty-two people from the
Baltimore-Washington area have formed
the Committee for Conversion of the APL.
The Committee is asking the University to
devote the entire resources of the Applied
Physics Laboratory (APL) to technologies
of peace, not of war; to develop systems
for human services, not systems for human
destruction.
The Committee particularly urges the
APL to cease work which might be related
in any way to the nuclear arms race.
Since 1942 the APL has developed
major components of weapons systems for
the United States military establishment.
The Laboratory designed the radio
proximity fuse during World War II.
It has since developed propulsion
systems, warheads and airframes for the
Terrier, Tartar and Tabs guided missiles
(the latter with nuclear capability) and
satellite navigation for the Polaris
submarines.
Military appropriations for FY 1976
include a Navy grant of $1.2 million to
APL for work on the Trident missile
system.
Nonviolence
The University Trustees established the
APL as a regular division of the University
in 1948. It continues as such now with FY
1973-74 expenditures of $90 million. In
1966 the APL devoted 8 per cent of its
budget to non-war applications. This has
increased and APL now devotes 20 per
cent of its budget to these programs.
However, the primary mission of the
APL, as a Federal Contract Research
Center, remains the application of
advanced science and technology to
problems of sophisticated warfare.
The Committee for Conversion has
already begun its non-violent campaign
with letters to the University's senior
administrators and Trustees who are
responsible for APL's relationship with the
government.
The Committee has based its campaign
in part on the assertion that nuclear
weapons can never be used morally, that
such weapons should therefore not exist

and that no one, certainly not university
people, should contribute to nuclear
weapons research and development.
The campaign is also based on the work
of Professor Seymour Melman of
Columbia University. He has suggested
that changing the use of labor and other
research and production resources form
military to civilian purposes is desirable so
that we may evaluate security problems on
their merits alone and not diffuse this
issue with considerations of livelihood and
economic well-being for labor forces,
industries, universities, etc.
He also has noted that military
economic activity, while contributing
wages and salaries to persons involved,
yields products that exit from the
marketplace upon being produced. These
products are not part of the current level
of living, except insofar as tbey contribute
to inflation.
Preliminary discussions with University
officials suggest that to its credit, the
APL has never refused a contract to
perform non-military work. However, they
indicated that currently available funds for
non-war work are insufficient to maintain
an efficiently functioning lab.
Consequently, without the APL's research
and development of weapons, there would
be no work in the fields of transportation,
biomedical engineering or civilian air
traffic control there.
Finally, the officers replied that Johns
Hopkins' contributions to U.S. military
weapons programs are quite appropriate
given present international relationships
which make unilateral disarmament
undesirable.
The Committee will continue to
communicate with University
administrators and with workers at APL.
They hope, too, that the broader issues of
the debate and the APL's current work
will stimulate thoughtful action by the
larger University community.
It is altogether appropriate that Johns
Hopkins, celebrating its centennial as a
leader in the American educational
community, should terminate its wasteful
association with the forces of war and
re-dedicate itself to that creative search for
truth for which it was founded.

Africa. The Dark Continent. Tarzan.
Lions and tigers. The natives and their
spears. Strange how our ignorance thrives
on such myths!, and how it's so difficult to
destroy these myths. Funny how we
Americans know what 'civilization' is.
Africa is dark only at night. I never saw
Tarzan. Only in a small portion of the
continent will you see wildlife, a la "Born
Free".(And there are no tigers in Africa.)
None of the 'natives' I met had spears.
Instead, I met a warm people in a country
called Ghana (formally the Gold Coast),
West Africa. I'm convinced after my nine
month stay in Ghana that I felt more at
home there than any Ghanaian could ever
feel at home in a country as 'civilized' as
America.
Ghanaians, as do many people of the
so-called 'third', or poor world have a lot
to teach us about being human. We might

Ghana was in people, not things. When
you don't have a lot it has to be that way.

Vonnegut relives insanity
By MICHAEL BELLOW
If you want to find out how a
schizophrenic person thinks and acts, the
best thing to do would be to go nuts
yourself. Not exactly relishing that
prospect, a second alternative is available,
Mark Vonnegut's recently published book,
The Eden Express, in which the son of a
favorite artist-in-words recounts his bout
with insanity.
Mark Vonnegut, a member of the class
of 1969 at Swarthmore College, graduated
with the feeling that life was not going his
way on the East Coast. After a year of
unrewarding work, he set out for British
Columbia, Canada, with the intention of
starting a utopian hippie community.
After setting up a farm along with
several friends in the unsoiled wilderness
where he had purchased his land, Mark
began to feel the peculiar sensations of
living in "Eden"—the beauty of the
surroundings, detachment from hectic life,
and sense of closeness to the others.
However, he soon could not control his
thousand-mile-an-hour thoughts and
insatiable desire to be understood by all
those around him. On trips away from the
farm, he was unable to function
normally—"Just getting back to the farm
where things made sense became
everything." Mark lost his ability to eat or
sleep and his weight decreased drastitally.
At last, with great reluctance, he was
placed 'in a psychiatric hospital.
Repulsed by the atmosphere of the nut
house, Mark succeeded in getting himself
released before he was completely cured.
Back in the hospital again after
succumbing to a drug orgy, he now
submitted faithfully to the prescribed
treatment and was successfully cured.
Feeling well and capable of handling life
outside of the farm, Mark went back East,
where he is now applying himself toward
educational pursuits.
Vonnegut describes graphically the life
of the farm—we see its ups and downs,
virtues and flaws. Each character is
distinctly portrayed—Virginia, with whom

Mark has a passionless but enduring love
affair; Simon, the practical bulwark; and
others. But Vonnegut's major intent is the
personal recollections of a schizophrenic
experience, and in this he certainlY
succeeds. Much is left vague; many aspects
of his experience cannot be recounted or
described.
In spite of the difficulty of putting such
phenomena into words, The Eden Express
is not really a difficult book. Mark seems
to have his father's talent for giving
effective expression to eccentric
experience. He can recall and relate manY
of the thoughts which raced through his
mind, and make us understand if not
appreciate them. In the final analysis.
Vonnegut rejects the belief that
schizophrenia requires a "poetic" cure and
recommends orthomolecular
therapy—treatment based on a vitamin
diet—as the most effective way that
science has yet developed for dealing with
this disease. Although he would not wish
schizophrenia on anyone, he maintains
that it can be "one of the richest learning
and humanizing experiences life offers."
Provided you recover, of course.
Vonnegut's attitude toward the farm
life is one of love and gentle irony in the
recollection. He admires the beauty of the
ideals which spurred on the project, but
has come to an understanding of
the impossibility of complete success for
any utopian attempt. He also realizes that
the world cannot be made better by
retreating from the mainstream of life.
The cause of his insanity he attributes not
to any specific event but to inevitable
mental factors within himself. However,
he failsito demonstrate convincingly that
external factors such as his parents'
marital troubles and his own affair with
Virginia played no major role in his loss of
mental balance. The Eden Express should
interest those who are not themselves
completely sound of mind, as well as
anyone who would like to learn how a
sound, intelligent mind can quickly go to
pieces and come back together again.

By D. H. WARREN
Chapter 4: The Origins ofPenflying-In
In those brief days between the
prehistoric age of Britain, and its more
tranquil feudal years, the established
nobles roamed across the green English
countryside looking for large family, one
bedroom, thatched huts. At such a place,
the nobles would call the peasant and his
family to a friendly round of
"Pencing-In". The peasant was always
eager to abide, sorely needing the few
pence he might gain. The coins were
Jammed into the lock and then, while the
Peasants all pushed and shoved against the
door, the hut was set on fire. The princes
would make wagers amongst themselves as
to whether or not the peasants would get
out, and if so—well, then when?
The jolly practice soon ceased when the
nobles started squabbling with themselves
and could no longer afford to fool around
so much.
—From Histories OfStrange
and Fascinating Games
Now that the above and a few other
interesting sports have become
popular—even, fashionable—once again at
the Alumni Memorial Residences, it is
only appropriate to look into the origins
of some of these games and what role they
have played in the Hopkins past. What
better way to begin celebrating that
Centennial year than by pennying-in
§teven Muller, eh? Most observers believe
that the penny-in hysteria started

Halloween night. But two weeks before
any underclassman had "de-cented"
himself, one 1Delmonica: Landover, a
transient Sicilian worker, sneaked into
Hollander and pennied-in an old classmate.
This year's residents are quick learners.
Back in 1968, when students all across
the country were angrily protesting the
Viet Nam war, Hopkins students were
busily pennying themselves in. Because of
their devotion to odd sports—a Hopkins
tradition—Hoppies never experienced
the height of the Flower Child. movement:
Vestiges of that era are still coming to the
campus, but the general attitude has been
that these people are disturbed and should
be taken care of properly. (I, as author of
this brief dissertation, stand in full
agreement with this majority opinion.
However, I reserve the right to change my
opinion due to a shift in popular opinion.)
On V-J Day in 1945, while strippers on
the block were getting ready for the boys
to come back home, the Hopkins cadets
were celebrating by pennying their fellow
residents in. Walter Sbrounie, then
temporary assistant to the Dean of
Students, while rehashing old times with
this reporter remembered that night:
"It was something else. There was this
one Frosh; nobody liked him at all, you
know, the really serious gonna get into
Med school type. Well, the combined
players of the football and lacrosse teams
descended on his floor and pennied him in
with one hundred steel pennies. It was a

proud moment."
Chapter 32: Hall-Flooding in the Colonies
As unfair taxes and strict customs laws
were being placed upon the already angry
American colonists, British troops began
their systematic harrassment of local
merchants by pumping ocean waters into
the small shops at peak business hours.
Although the floods never reached more
than a foot in height, the damage was
costly and the sorry task of cleaning up
the mess gave rise to the expression,
"Sucking the Big Mop." The successful
Revolution put an end to these incidents
until 1835, when several of the Ivy League
schools reinstated the floods as part of the
official hazing program.
—From Military Diversions
Through the Ages
Hall-flooding arrived late this year,
missing the usual Orientation rush.
However, the calculated planning which
produced the unified movement of five
hundred gallons of water from one
dormitory to another set a new Hopkins
record, overturning the long held record
on 1956. That . was when Malcolm P.
Lennox singlehandedly flooded the Office
of Residential Life, and replaced goldfish
swallowing as the number one campus
sport. Lennox had no comment for the
press when informed of the new record.
Friends have told us that he still feels he
should be the one we remember since he
did it all alone.
Periodically, hall-flooding has

degenerated into individualized
dowsing—which during the Middle Ages
had been collective—and there occurs the
unfair tactic of pitting several agile
residents against one unsuspecting peer.
The critics frown on this method, pointing
out that it does not serve the spirit Of
friendly competition.
The origins of the spraying of shaving
cream are uncertain, but recent
anthropological studies tend to associate
the act with fertility rituals. This may
explain the lack of such behavior at single
sex colleges and the first sign of the
sprayings at Hopkins coinciding with the
coeducational move of 1970. Enthusiasts
recommend menthol-scented shaving
cream for the most tasteful results.
Occasionally, participants report becoming
sidetracked in creating designs on the
bathroom mirrors.
The popular resurgence of this sport in
the Residences this semester has led to the
formation of numerous teams, each
competing for the coveted Noxzema Cup,
to be presented at the end of the academic
year. A strong rivalry exists between male
and female dormitories where getting
sprayed is equivalent to being raped.
The season ahead looks promising.
There should be no break in the action,
with staunch supporters vowing an
Intersession drive. The future for these
easy- to-take-part-in, fun-to-be-in sports
should be plentiful and full or surprises.
Don't close your doors too hard.

green parrot as I left the bird house.

flashed me a self-satisfied grin oyerflowirr

By RICHARD FREEMAN

Twenty-two people from the
Baltimore-Washington area have formed
the Committee for Conversion of the APL.
The Committee is asking the University to
devote the entire resources of the Applied
Physics Laboratory (APL) to technologies
of peace, not of war; to develop systems
for human services, not systems for human
destruction.
The Committee particularly urges the
APL to cease work which might be related
in any way to the nuclear arms race.
Since 1942 the APL has developed
major components of weapons systems for
the United States military establishment.
The Laboratory designed the radio
proximity fuse during World War II.
It has since developed propulsion
systems, warheads and airframes for the
Terrier, Tartar and Tabs guided missiles
(the latter with nuclear capability) and
satellite navigation for the Polaris
submarines.
Military appropriations for FY 1976
include a Navy grant of $1.2 million to
APL for work on the Trident missile
system.
Nonviolence
The University Trustees established the
APL as a regular division of the University
in 1948. It continues as such now with FY
1973-74 expenditures of $90 million. In
1966 the APL devoted 8 per cent of its
budget to non-war applications. This has
increased and APL now devotes 20 per
cent of its budget to these programs.
However, the primary mission of the
APL, as a Federal Contract Research
Center, remains the application of
advanced science and technology to
problems of sophisticated warfare.
The Committee for Conversion has
already begun its non-violent campaign
with letters to the University's senior
administrators and Trustees who are
responsible for APL's relationship with the
government.
The Committee has based its campaign
in part on the assertion that nuclear
weapons can never be used morally, that
such weapons should therefore not exist

and that no one, certainly not university
people, should contribute to nuclear
weapons research and development.
The campaign is also based on the work
of Professor Seymour Melman of
Columbia University. He has suggested
that changing the use of labor and other
research and production resources form
military to civilian purposes is desirable so
that we may evaluate security problems on
their merits alone and not diffuse this
issue with considerations of livelihood and
economic well-being for labor forces,
industries, universities, etc.
He also has noted that military
economic activity, while contributing
wages and salaries to persons involved,
yields products that exit from the
marketplace upon being produced. These
products are not part of the current level
of living, except insofar as tbey contribute
to inflation.
Preliminary discussions with University
officials suggest that to its credit, the
APL has never refused a contract to
perform non-military work. However, they
indicated that currently available funds for
non-war work are insufficient to maintain
an efficiently functioning lab.
Consequently, without the APL's research
and development of weapons, there would
be no work in the fields of transportation,
biomedical engineering or civilian air
traffic control there.
Finally, the officers replied that Johns
Hopkins' contributions to U.S. military
weapons programs are quite appropriate
given present international relationships
which make unilateral disarmament
undesirable.
The Committee will continue to
communicate with University
administrators and with workers at APL.
They hope, too, that the broader issues of
the debate and the APL's current work
will stimulate thoughtful action by the
larger University community.
It is altogether appropriate that Johns
Hopkins, celebrating its centennial as a
leader in the American educational
community, should terminate its wasteful
association with the forces of war and
re-dedicate itself to that creative search for
truth for which it was founded.

By JOHN HOLDREN
If you are one of those faithful of
Crosby, Stills, Nash, and Young, from way
back when, then you've probably found
your pocket money dwindling lately, since
all the boys have released individual
efforts in the past few months. As for
myself, I feel gypped in at least two out of
three purchases. The new Crosby-Nash
collaboration, Wind on the Water, is
recycled mishmash. It must be that Messrs.
David and Graham feel fleeting youth
slipping from their gasp (alas!), for, with
all the subtlety of a pile-driver, they seem
to be attempting to make their music have
some kind of lasting artistic and social
significance. It doesn't work. They employ
some o f the finest studio musiciarfs
available, who, despite their talents,
cannot help but sound a bit put off, if not
bored, by all this pretentiousness. Crosby
blunders embarrassingly in thinking that
making a literary allusion equals being
"poetic," e.g.: "How could Samson / I
thought he was blind as a bat! How could
he have torn down / a temple like that?"
As if that weren't enough, we get, just
what we need, another save-the-whale
ecology song. Singing about whales is not,
dammit, going to save any, nor is it going
to inspire your average record buyer to
rush out and strike down some Japanese
Ahab with his atomic harpoon. Previous
Crosby and Nash solo albums or
collaborations all had a lot going for them:
this one just sputters.
As for Stephen Stills' new album
(entitled, gee, that's funny, Stills), I have
no one but myself to blame for wasting
my money on it. His earlier efforts
dictated that this most recent one would
be just another monomaniac ego-show,
and, yes, it is. A friend of mine lauds the
album for "precision," but then again, he
also gets a charge out listening to accutron
watches.
So that leaves us with Neil Young, and
that's wfio I really want to talk about. His new
album,. just out, comes only a few months
after his release of the Degenerate Album
of the Year, Tonight's the Night,
which—despite the fact that it initially
Sounds/like something you would record
after pulling a week; (at least) of
all-fighters—I find to be one of the most
interesting and (if there is such a thing)
significant rock albums in a long time. In
it, Young reveals that starkly candid side
of a performer we so rarely see: or wait a
minute, is it just another part of a big

performance? If you can keep yourself
from turning it off, you'll inevitably start
to flow with it. Listen to it at least once,
just to catch those amazing lines that
weird Neil Young can get away with, while
they would sound like ridiculously puerile
attempts at freakiness if Stills or the other
guys tried to pull them off. For example:
"I'm singing this borrowed tune /1 took
from the Rolling Stones / Alone in this
empty room / Too wasted to write my
own;" or, on the lighter side, "I'm not
.going back to Woodstock for awhile I
Though I long to hear that lonesome
hippie smile." Such lines should be heard,
however, not read, for in Young's, er,
unique voice lies much of their effect.
Neil Young ,
Neil Young's brand new album is called
Zuma. The title, if you're wondering, is an
abridgement of the name Montezuma, the
last chieftain, of the Aztec tribe laid to
waste by Cortez, whose achievement
Young puts in perspective in his song,
"Cortez the Killer." Before listening to

could have gone had they not disbanded.

working together, all four can produce

impatiently hope that they get together
for one more extended try. In the
meantime, Zuma can keep me, and maybe
you, plenty entertained.

Vonnegut relives insanity
By MICHAEL BELLOW
If you want to find out how a
schizophrenic person thinks and acts, the
best thing to do would be to go nuts
yourself. Not exactly relishing that
prospect, a second alternative is available,
Mark Vonnegut's recently published book,
The Eden Express, in which the son of a
favorite artist-in-words recounts his bout
with insanity.
Mark Vonnegut, a member of the class
of 1969 at Swarthmore College, graduated
with the feeling that life was not going his
way on the East Coast. After a year of
unrewarding work, he set out for British
Columbia, Canada, with the intention of
starting a utopian hippie community.
After setting up a farm along with
several friends in the unsoiled wilderness
where he had purchased his land, Mark
began to feel the peculiar sensations of
living in "Eden"—the beauty of the
surroundings, detachment from hectic life,
and sense of closeness to the others.
However, he soon could not control his
thousand-mile-an-hour thoughts and
insatiable desire to be understood by all
those around him. On trips away from the
farm, he was unable to function
normally—"Just getting back to the farm
where things made sense became
everything." Mark lost his ability to eat or
sleep and his weight decreased drastitally.
At last, with great reluctance, he was
placed 'in a psychiatric hospital.
Repulsed by the atmosphere of the nut
house, Mark succeeded in getting himself
released before he was completely cured.
Back in the hospital again after
succumbing to a drug orgy, he now
submitted faithfully to the prescribed
treatment and was successfully cured.
Feeling well and capable of handling life
outside of the farm, Mark went back East,
where he is now applying himself toward
educational pursuits.
Vonnegut describes graphically the life
of the farm—we see its ups and downs,
virtues and flaws. Each character is
distinctly portrayed—Virginia, with whom

Mark has a passionless but enduring love
affair; Simon, the practical bulwark; and
others. But Vonnegut's major intent is the
personal recollections of a schizophrenic
experience, and in this he certainlY
succeeds. Much is left vague; many aspects
of his experience cannot be recounted or
described.
In spite of the difficulty of putting such
phenomena into words, The Eden Express
is not really a difficult book. Mark seems
to have his father's talent for giving
effective expression to eccentric
experience. He can recall and relate manY
of the thoughts which raced through his
mind, and make us understand if not
appreciate them. In the final analysis.
Vonnegut rejects the belief that
schizophrenia requires a "poetic" cure and
recommends orthomolecular
therapy—treatment based on a vitamin
diet—as the most effective way that
science has yet developed for dealing with
this disease. Although he would not wish
schizophrenia on anyone, he maintains
that it can be "one of the richest learning
and humanizing experiences life offers."
Provided you recover, of course.
Vonnegut's attitude toward the farm
life is one of love and gentle irony in the
recollection. He admires the beauty of the
ideals which spurred on the project, but
has come to an understanding of
the impossibility of complete success for
any utopian attempt. He also realizes that
the world cannot be made better by
retreating from the mainstream of life.
The cause of his insanity he attributes not
to any specific event but to inevitable
mental factors within himself. However,
he failsito demonstrate convincingly that
external factors such as his parents'
marital troubles and his own affair with
Virginia played no major role in his loss of
mental balance. The Eden Express should
interest those who are not themselves
completely sound of mind, as well as
anyone who would like to learn how a
sound, intelligent mind can quickly go to
pieces and come back together again.

"UPTIGHT about schools...or just
about the Niggers?"
"Are you really uptight because White

"Boating, not busing! Africa, not our

creation just for the "cultural experience"

than do Whites."
"Race-Mixing stinks...but not half as
bad as the pornographic Jews who
Promote it! The sick, depraved Jews who
monopolize the motion-picture industry
can hardly wait to turn American into a
mongrel cesspool."
Are there people who sincerely support
all of this? There are, and they're
organized in Baltimore.
My first contact with this apparent
insanity came sometime during my
freshman year. A friend happened upon a
phone number that supposedly could put
us in touch with the local Nazi Party
headquarters. At that time we were in the
habit of exploiting the phone as a means
of entertainment, so within minutes we
were huddled over the receiver listening to
the recorded message in complete
disbelief. I can't recall the particulars of
the message, but I distinctly recall the
reaction of my Jewish accomplice. In his
own words, "I'm going to go down there
and throw a brick through the window."
Months later the subject came up again.
A re-indoctrination took place. In the
course of driving out to Icaros, the

universally -acknowledged Greek
restaurant, we passed a bizarre store front
on Eastern Ave. There was a Nazi flag,
complete with Swastika, hanging right
alongside an American counterpart. A
crudely lettered sign, with enough racial
slurs to turn anyone's head, announced
that this was the headquarters of The
National Socialist White People's Party.
We began calling again.
After two years of speculation, I finally
found myself headed down to 2112
Eastern Ave. in the company of a friend
who was to take pictures, and who
happens to be Jewish. I approached the
door with some apprehension while Gary
stood outside taking pictures of the
streetside display and bolstering his
courage. Fortunately I knew exactly what
to expect inside. The Sunday Sun
Magazine ran a two column story in the
Sundries section that accurately depicted
both the interior of the bookstore and
Wolfgang Schrodt, the proprietor. Had I
not had this preparation in advance, I
might have broken into a sweat as well.
As I climbed the steps I immediately
noticed Wolfgang looming in the door in
front of me, possibly observing Gary's
photographic activities from across the
street. He opened the door for me and I
proceeded to gape. It was exactly as I had
imagined it. Nazi flags and SS banners
we re displayed profusely along with
numerous posters of Hitler, a podium, a
shelf of German war medal reproductions
and of course racks of books and leaflets.
And Wolfgang proudly wore a thirty-eight
in a black leather holster on his hip, true
to the description in the Sun. Rimless
glasses, a thin black tie and white shirt,
and a closely cropped moustache further
defined the character. A massive

Rhodesian bushhound leaped up in an
obviously unaffectionate way.
Fortunately, he was chained to a pipe in
the rear of the room.
I began to "browse," fumbling through
free hand-outs that displayed the kind of
sensational insight that was quoted at the
beginning of this article. I attempted to
strike up a conversation with Wolfgang,
whomI knew from a phone message earlier
this fall as the Party's candidate for first
district councilman. Wolfgang was cordial
beyond all of my expectations. After
feeding him a few carefully prepared lines
about reverse racism in gaining entrance to
med school, he really opened up. His

speech was punctuated with words such as
Nigger-scum, filth, savages, animals and
Jew-bastards. He conveyed a blanket
hatred for all non-Aryans living in the
United States. He responded favorably to
Gary's question about Hitler's Youth
Corps, of which he was a member. He
commented on the political ideology of
The Party, which, while limited to the
Aryan race, seemed vaguely to correspond
with my limited knowledge of socialist
principles. Wolfgang contended that
communism was a fine idea, but in the
Soviet Union the Jews have an
uncontested strangle-hold.
Incredibly, we spent a full forty-five
minutes chatting with Wolfgang, dutifully
listening and posing conservative
questions. Our purpose was not to differ,
which might have been unwise, but to
elicit and ascertain that all we had heard
over the past few years was for real. It was
easy enough for me to stay relatively
composed, while Gary struggled and
sweated through the occasional ominous
glances at his naturally curly hair. We
weren't sure whether Wolfgang knew or
not, but the fact is that it really didn't
matter. He posed no threat, as perverse as
his opinions might have been.
He gave absolutely no indication as to
how strong the party is. I seriously doubt
that Wolfgang will be the next first district
councilman, or that the party will solicit
many new members in the Baltimore area.
They are a benign, non-violent group that
exists more as a curiosity than a
malevolent subversive force. The opening
of the bookstore three years ago incited a
few local riots, but things have been quiet,
almost sleepy since then. The phone
answering service flashes excitedly, while
Wolfgang fingers his cigar placidly.

By D. H. WARREN
Chapter 4: The Origins ofPenflying-In
In those brief days between the
prehistoric age of Britain, and its more
tranquil feudal years, the established
nobles roamed across the green English
countryside looking for large family, one
bedroom, thatched huts. At such a place,
the nobles would call the peasant and his
family to a friendly round of
"Pencing-In". The peasant was always
eager to abide, sorely needing the few
pence he might gain. The coins were
Jammed into the lock and then, while the
Peasants all pushed and shoved against the
door, the hut was set on fire. The princes
would make wagers amongst themselves as
to whether or not the peasants would get
out, and if so—well, then when?
The jolly practice soon ceased when the
nobles started squabbling with themselves
and could no longer afford to fool around
so much.
—From Histories OfStrange
and Fascinating Games
Now that the above and a few other
interesting sports have become
popular—even, fashionable—once again at
the Alumni Memorial Residences, it is
only appropriate to look into the origins
of some of these games and what role they
have played in the Hopkins past. What
better way to begin celebrating that
Centennial year than by pennying-in
§teven Muller, eh? Most observers believe
that the penny-in hysteria started

Halloween night. But two weeks before
any underclassman had "de-cented"
himself, one 1Delmonica: Landover, a
transient Sicilian worker, sneaked into
Hollander and pennied-in an old classmate.
This year's residents are quick learners.
Back in 1968, when students all across
the country were angrily protesting the
Viet Nam war, Hopkins students were
busily pennying themselves in. Because of
their devotion to odd sports—a Hopkins
tradition—Hoppies never experienced
the height of the Flower Child. movement:
Vestiges of that era are still coming to the
campus, but the general attitude has been
that these people are disturbed and should
be taken care of properly. (I, as author of
this brief dissertation, stand in full
agreement with this majority opinion.
However, I reserve the right to change my
opinion due to a shift in popular opinion.)
On V-J Day in 1945, while strippers on
the block were getting ready for the boys
to come back home, the Hopkins cadets
were celebrating by pennying their fellow
residents in. Walter Sbrounie, then
temporary assistant to the Dean of
Students, while rehashing old times with
this reporter remembered that night:
"It was something else. There was this
one Frosh; nobody liked him at all, you
know, the really serious gonna get into
Med school type. Well, the combined
players of the football and lacrosse teams
descended on his floor and pennied him in
with one hundred steel pennies. It was a

proud moment."
Chapter 32: Hall-Flooding in the Colonies
As unfair taxes and strict customs laws
were being placed upon the already angry
American colonists, British troops began
their systematic harrassment of local
merchants by pumping ocean waters into
the small shops at peak business hours.
Although the floods never reached more
than a foot in height, the damage was
costly and the sorry task of cleaning up
the mess gave rise to the expression,
"Sucking the Big Mop." The successful
Revolution put an end to these incidents
until 1835, when several of the Ivy League
schools reinstated the floods as part of the
official hazing program.
—From Military Diversions
Through the Ages
Hall-flooding arrived late this year,
missing the usual Orientation rush.
However, the calculated planning which
produced the unified movement of five
hundred gallons of water from one
dormitory to another set a new Hopkins
record, overturning the long held record
on 1956. That . was when Malcolm P.
Lennox singlehandedly flooded the Office
of Residential Life, and replaced goldfish
swallowing as the number one campus
sport. Lennox had no comment for the
press when informed of the new record.
Friends have told us that he still feels he
should be the one we remember since he
did it all alone.
Periodically, hall-flooding has

degenerated into individualized
dowsing—which during the Middle Ages
had been collective—and there occurs the
unfair tactic of pitting several agile
residents against one unsuspecting peer.
The critics frown on this method, pointing
out that it does not serve the spirit Of
friendly competition.
The origins of the spraying of shaving
cream are uncertain, but recent
anthropological studies tend to associate
the act with fertility rituals. This may
explain the lack of such behavior at single
sex colleges and the first sign of the
sprayings at Hopkins coinciding with the
coeducational move of 1970. Enthusiasts
recommend menthol-scented shaving
cream for the most tasteful results.
Occasionally, participants report becoming
sidetracked in creating designs on the
bathroom mirrors.
The popular resurgence of this sport in
the Residences this semester has led to the
formation of numerous teams, each
competing for the coveted Noxzema Cup,
to be presented at the end of the academic
year. A strong rivalry exists between male
and female dormitories where getting
sprayed is equivalent to being raped.
The season ahead looks promising.
There should be no break in the action,
with staunch supporters vowing an
Intersession drive. The future for these
easy- to-take-part-in, fun-to-be-in sports
should be plentiful and full or surprises.
Don't close your doors too hard.

Jay shooters take two meets
By BETH TERRANOVA
After a disappointing defeat at the
hands of Dickinson College in their first
meet of the season, the Hopkins varsity
rifle team rallied to take both of their next
two matches.
Encouraged somewhat by the fact that
the Dickinson meet was a close one, the
Jays travelled to the home of defending
league champs Mount Saint Mary's on
November 7. With their 1161-1087 upset
victory, the Homewood rifles handed the
Mount their first defeat in over a year.
Mt. St. Mary's has been led by the
efforts of Tim Bradshaw, the top shooter
in the league, and strong back-up shooters.
This year, however, the back-up was
missing as Bradshaw's 262 stood out as the
only really high score for the team.
Double Winner
Hopkins, on the other hand, amassed
rive good, fairly close scores to pull out
the win. Beth Terranova led with a 248,
followed by John Laczin (231), Sukon
Kanchariaraksa (229), Glenn Horner
(227), and Glen Stewart (226).
"The scores weren't all that high,"
commented Horner, "but they're solid.
That is, there's no great fluctuation
between any two scores. That's what
happened to Mt. St. Mary's—there just

wasn't much to count after Bradshaw."
On November 15, the rifle team went
on to defeat Howard University by the
wide margin of 352 points. However, the
1190-838 victory must be viewed in the
light of the fact that Howard is a new
team in the league and is not even
recognized by their university officials due
to fear of injuries on the range, though
there have been none to date.
"You have to respect them," said one
Hopkins team member. "They manage to
keep interest in the team, and they raise
their own funds. They're shooting mainly
for the fun of it. They're nice people. You
almost hate to win against a team like
that."
But like it or not, the Hopkins team put
together their highest score of the season,
with Beth Terranova again leading the
scoring with a 258. Glenn Homer followed
with a 247 and Tony Moss placed third
with a 237. Also placing were John Laczin
(231) and Glen Stewart (217). And of
those shooters not placing, no one was
under 200.
Due to some scheduling changes, the
rifle team will not have another meet until
the end of January, when they will face
their toughest opponent of the year at
Georgetown.

Swordsmen cut wide swath
By GARY SWIMMER
The Hopkins fencing team returns this
year with an incredible season behind it,
but sizeable pressure to attain the same
kind of success by this year's end. This is
especially true because of the loss ofsome
of the key components of last year's 28-5
squad.
Returning lettermen, who carry both
the MAC and NAC titles are led by new
co-captains, epeeman Tim Rodgers and
sabreman Ron Kramer. The other Blue
Jays who boast these distinctions are
epeeman, Torn Slota, (who tied with
Rodgers for the MAC epee title), sabreman
Frank Burton, who finished in second
place at the MAC's last year, and foilman
Dave Bell. Epeemen Charlie Eck and
Frank Murabito, and foilman George
Antonides are other returning lettermen.
Already into preseason competition, the
fencers have scored victories in scrimmages
over new MAC rival, Lehigh and Hopkins'
own alumni team.
Cliffhanger
Their victory over Lehigh was a 23-4
rout but the A4umni meet came down to
the wire. As it turned out, the entire meet
came down to the final point in the final
bout, be fore freshman foilman Eric
Newman scored the deciding touch to win
5-4 and secure the narrow 14-13 win for
the Jays.
Newman's performance is only one
example of the potential of the

newcomers to break into the starting
lineup. The other new faces are
sophomore sabremen St reamson Chua and
Bob Meade, and foilman Dave Brabarek.
This talent is what the Blue Jays have
gained, what they have lost with the end
of last season were three key starters, two
of whom, John Roberts and Bruce
Livingston, may have been the most
versatile and outstanding fencers Hopkins
has ever had. All three, lost to graduation,
were All-Conference; Livingston
performing first in sabre and ably adapting
to foil to round out an ailing foilteam ;
Roberts, having been the only fencer ever
to take the MAC sabre crown, undefeated,
for two consecutive years.
What the fencers are now faced with is a
tough season against strong national
competition. They have many talented,
but untested fencers in their ranks. The
epee team is .the only one returning intact.
The sabre team has mainly new faces and
the foil team also has gone through major
renovations. All this adds up to
"rebuilding" year for Coach Richard Oles'
swashbucklers.
The co-captains see the
season's results balancing on the steady
performance of the epee team and
whether foil flowers or folds.
Blue Jay fencing fans can get their first
look at this year's squad when the Jays
scrimmage Baltimore's amateur fencing
club, Salle Palacz, Saturday afternoon in
the Homewood fencing room.
